Tel.: +886 3 4227151x34203; fax: +886 3 4252296. Graphical abstract HRTEM image of Au/Co3O4–TiO2 shows 2nm Au nanoparticles on the vicinity of Co3O4 and TiO2. Co3O4 deposited on anatase TiO2. The amorphous nature of Co3O4 along with TiO2 not only enhances electronic interaction but also stabilizes the nano-size gold particles, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity of CO towards higher extent and suppresses H2 oxidation. Highlights ► Co3O4 was added to Au/TiO2 to suppress H2 oxidation without sacrificing the activity for CO oxidation. ► The amorphous nature of Co3O4 along with TiO2 stabilizes the nano-size gold particles. ► Au/Co3O4–TiO2 is a good catalyst for preferential oxidation of CO in H2 stream. A series of Au catalysts supported on Co3O4–TiO2 with various Co contents were prepared. Co3O4–TiO2 support was prepared by incipient-wetness impregnation with aqueous solution of Co(NO3)3 on TiO2. Gold catalyst was prepared by deposition–precipitation at pH 7 and 65°C. The catalysts were characterized by ICP-MS, XRD, TEM, HRTEM and XPS. The catalytic performance of these catalysts was investigated by preferential oxidation of carbon monoxide in hydrogen stream (PROX). The reaction was carried out in a fixed bed reactor with feed of CO:O2:H2:He=1.33:1.33:65.33:32.01 (volume ratios). Au/TiO2 catalyst had both high CO oxidation activity and high H2 oxidation activity. Adding suitable amount of Co3O4 on Au/TiO2 could enhance CO conversion to a higher extent and suppress H2 oxidation. On Au/TiO2 catalysts, gold nucleates at oxygen defect sites of anatase TiO2 and remains highly dispersed and in good contact with the support. The gold atoms directly in contact with TiO2 are positively charged and highly stable. Doping with cobalt oxide increases the number of oxygen defects on TiO2, thus leading to a higher concentration of strongly bound gold atoms. The amorphous nature of Co3O4 along with TiO2 not only enhances electronic interaction between Au and Co3O4–TiO2, but also stabilizes the nano-size gold particles, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity of CO towards higher extent. Keywords Gold catalyst Hydrogen energy CO oxidation PROX TiO2 Co3O4 1 Introduction Gold-based catalyst has been proved to be effective for CO oxidation at ambient temperature [1] and appears as a promising candidate for CO PROX reaction [2]. Nanoscale gold–oxide systems evaluated in the recent years as PROX catalysts include Au/Al2O3 [3], Au/Fe2O3 [4,5], Au/TiO2 [6], Au/Ti-SBA-15 [7], Au/CeO2 [8], Au/MnO2–TiO2 [9] and so on. Schubert et al. [10] found that Au/CeO2 and Au/Co3O4 exhibited high activity in CO PROX. The suitable supports are the reducible metal oxides, such as TiO2, α-Fe2O3, MnO x , and Co3O4 [11–13]. The most intensively studied catalyst for CO oxidation is Au/TiO2 as neither Au nor TiO2 is active for CO oxidation but their combination generates surprisingly high catalytic activity. On Au/TiO2 catalysts, the reaction was observed even at temperature as low as 90K [14]. A number of catalysts have been investigated for the PROX reaction. Some of the more effective ones include supported-Pt [15–17], Ru [18], and Au [19]. There are two reactions in PROX reactor: (1) CO+1/2O2 →CO2 (2) H2 +1/2O2 →H2O Both are highly exothermic. Since only limited amount of O2 was fed into the reactor, how to increase CO conversion and suppress H2 conversion is the main task, and catalyst plays an important role. Using Au-containing catalysts, it has been reported that the operating temperatures can be lowered to ∼80°C to achieve similar results [20]. Au/Co3O4 was more active than Au/TiO2 catalyst because Co3O4 is a more easily reducible support and because the disordered structure facilitated the formation of anion vacancies near gold particles thereby enhancing the catalytic activity. Liu and Vannice [21] have reported that the deposition of TiO2 on the surface of Au markedly enhances the catalytic activity for CO oxidation. It has been known that the Co/TiO2 catalyst was considered to have a strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) and showed high activity in CO hydrogenation [22,23]. This interaction is an important factor for determining the properties of Co/TiO2 catalyst such as cobalt dispersion and reduction behavior [24]. In fact, the synthesis of highly dispersed cobalt on TiO2 support requires the strong interaction between cobalt and support. However, too strong interaction can produce the Co-support compound as a suboxide at an interface that is high resistant to reduction [25,26]. Au/Co3O4 was recognized as one of the most active catalyst for methane oxidation, among a series of co-precipitated Au on several transition metal oxides [27]. The structural promotion by CeO2 of a Co3O4 catalyst was observed in methane total oxidation [28,29]. The positive effect was attributed to an improved thermal stability, and an increased dispersion of Au metal. Cobalt is particularly active and possesses a high activity for CO and hydrocarbon oxidation [30]. Promotion of Pd with Co results in increased CO and propene oxidation activities under stoichiometric conditions [20]. One of the authors has reported that MnO2, Fe2O3, MgO and CuO are suitable promoters for Au/TiO2 and Au/CeO2 catalysts for PROX reaction [9,14,31–39]. There are several literature reports on Au/TiO2 and Au/Co3O4 for PROX reaction, but the results on Au/Co3O4–TiO2 are scarce in literature. In this study, the effects of Co3O4 additive on Au/TiO2 for PROX reaction were investigated. Co3O4 is reducible and can be in amorphous state or in hydroxide state, which will provide many hydroxyl groups. It also has strong interaction with Au. Therefore, it was expected to create synergistic effect with Au/TiO2. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Co3O4–TiO2 supports were prepared by incipient-wetness impregnation method. The mixed metal oxides were prepared by varying the molar ratios of metal oxide and titania. Co(NO3)2·6H2O was added to distilled water of quantity equal to the pore volume of TiO2. The solution was added into TiO2 powder in drops under vigorous grinding and then calcined for 4h at 300°C. Gold catalysts were prepared by deposition–precipitation method. HAuCl4 solution (1g in 1l distilled water) was added at a rate 10ml/min into a solution containing suspended support under vigorous stirring and the precipitation temperature of solution was maintained at 65°C. Ammonia solution was used to adjust the pH value at 7. After aging for 2h, the precipitate was filtered and washed with hot water (65°C) until no Cl− was detected with AgNO3 solution, and dried at 80°C for 12h. The cake was grounded and calcined at 180°C for 4h to obtain gold catalysts. The amount of gold loaded on the supported catalysts corresponds to 1wt.%. The catalyst is denoted as Au/Co3O4–TiO2 (x:y) where x:y is the atomic ratio of Co:Ti in the starting materials. 2.2 Characterization The catalysts were characterized by inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry (ICP-MS), X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM). The exact gold content was analyzed with ICP-MS (PE/SCIEX Elan 6100 DRC). The ICP-MS was used for the reduction of plasma-based interferences. The catalysts were first dissolved in hot aqua regia and then microwaved for 15min. The solution was cooled down and diluted with demineralized water to concentrations within the detection range of the instrument. To release mechanical stress from the inclusion, a small beam size was used to open the inclusion, followed by successive enlargement of the ablation pit. Hydrogen was used as reaction gas for the removal of plasma based interferences when operated at DRC mode. Quantitative results were calculated after calibration of the instrument response using SRM NIST 610 or 612 and a halite for Cl. Al-bulk concentrations, determined by electron microprobe, were used as internal standard in the case of the melt inclusions. The advantage from this gain in sensitivity is shown by the transient signal for a melt inclusion (40μm diameter) from the Mole Granite. The comparison between standard and DRC operation mode shows an excellent agreement between the concentrations obtained for a series of fluid inclusions. XRD experiments were performed using a Siemens D8-A powder diffractometer. The XRD patterns were collected using Cu Kα1 radiation (1.5405Å) at a voltage and current of 40kV and 40mA, respectively. The sample was scanned over the range 2θ =20–70° at a speed of 3°/min to identify the crystalline structure. The samples for XRD were prepared as thin layers on a sample holder. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) was performed on each of the sample. First the sample was treated in 100ml/min argon at 100°C for 1h to remove any adsorbed gases or water. Then 25ml/min 5% H2 in Ar was flowed through the sample while the temperature was ramped from 25 to 720°C at a rate of 10°C/min. During each of these steps the process was monitored using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD), and the resulting current was plotted to quantify the consumption of H2. The morphologies and particle sizes of the samples were determined by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) on a JEM-2000 FX II (JEOL) operated at 120kV and 160kV. HRTEM on a JEOL JEM-2010 was operated at 160kV. The samples were ground, suspended in methanol at room temperature and dispersed with ultrasonic agitation; then, an aliquot of the solution was dropped on a 3mm diameter carbon film supported on lacey copper grid. The average particle size (ds) of the Au particles was calculated by the following equation: d s = ∑ n i d i 3 / ∑ n i d i 2 , where d i is the diameter measured directly from the TEM micrographs; and n i is the number of particles having the diameter d i . From each catalyst, about 200 Au particles were measured in order to determine a statistically justified average particle size and size distribution. XPS spectra were recorded with a Thermo VG Scientific Sigma Prob spectrometer. The powder samples were pressed onto a special sample holder, which was then placed in a vacuum chamber. The XPS spectrometer was equipped with a hemispherical electron analyzer and an Al Kα X-ray radiation source (hν =1486.6eV) powered at 20kV and 30mA. The residual pressure in the chamber was below 5×10−9 Torr. The base pressure in the analyzing chamber was maintained in the order of 10−9 Torr. The spectrometer was operated at 23.5eV pass energy. The intensities of the peaks were estimated by calculating the integral peak after subtracting an S-shaped background and fitting the experimental peak to a combination of Lorentzian/Gaussian lines of variable proportions. The binding energy of XPS was corrected by contaminant carbon (C 1s =284.5eV) in order to facilitate the comparisons of the values among the catalysts and the standard compounds. 2.3 Catalytic activity Catalytic reaction tests were performed in a similar manner as reported previously [9,31]. The catalytic measurements of CO oxidation in hydrogen stream were carried out in a downward, fixed-bed continuous-flow, pyrex glass-tubular reactor loaded with 0.1g of catalyst. The reactant gas containing 1.33% CO, 1.33% O2 and 65.33% H2, and He for balance was fed into the reactor with a total flow rate of 50cm3/min. The reactor was heated with a temperature regulated furnace with a heating rate of 1°C/min and the temperature was measured by a thermocouple placed inside the catalyst bed. The outlet gas was analyzed by a gas chromatograph (China Chromatography 8700T) equipped with MS-5A column and thermal conductivity detector. Calibration of the gases was done with a standard gas containing known concentration of the components. The influent and effluent gases were analyzed by a six-port auto-sampling valve in an on-line gas chromatograph, which was equipped with a packed Carbosphere column (80/100 mesh and 10ft 1/8in.) and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Since the change of hydrogen concentrations in the stream was very little, one was not able to measure it by gas chromatograph. The selectivity of oxygen reacting with hydrogen was calculated by O2 consumption and CO consumption. The CO and O2 conversion calculations were based on the CO and O2 consumption, respectively. The selectivity of oxygen reacting with CO (CO selectivity) was calculated by the ratio of O2 consumption for the CO oxidation reaction to the total O2 consumption. The CO conversion and selectivity of O2 reacting with CO (S%) were calculated as follows: (3) CO conversion ( X CO % ) = [ CO ] in − [ CO ] out [ CO ] in × 100 % (4) O 2 conversion ( X O 2 % ) = [ O 2 ] in − [ O 2 ] out [ O 2 ] in × 100 % (5) Selectivity of O 2 reacting with CO ( S % ) = 0.5 × X CO X O 2 × 100 % = mol of O 2 reacting with CO mol of O 2 consumed 3 Results and discussion 3.1 ICP-MS ICP-MS results shown in Table 1 reveal the amount of exact Au loadings and Co loadings on the support. In this study, the nominal Au loading in the starting material was 1wt.% for all catalysts. The results show that about 70% of Au in the starting material was deposited on the support. The results are in good agreement with the literature data. It is difficult to gain complete deposition of gold on the support by deposition–precipitation method. The results infer that adding Co3O4 on TiO2 did not significantly change the isoelectric point of TiO2. 3.2 XRD Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of Au/Co3O4–TiO2 with various Co/Ti ratios. All catalysts containing TiO2 support showed intense XRD peaks for anatase phase 2θ =25.23° (101), 37.72° (004), 47.89° (200), 53.77° (105) and 62.51° (204) and rutile phase 2θ =27.45° (110), 36.10° (101) and 54.36° (211), since the P25 sample from Evonik Degussa contains both anatase and rutile phases. The characteristic peaks for Co3O4 were weak. Since cobalt species were added by incipient-wetness, cobalt species was present on the surface of TiO2. The high proportion of cobalt oxide that was not incorporated into the titania network can be present as very small cobalt oxide conglomerates undetectable by XRD even at high cobalt oxide contents. It must be noted that in the enlarged XRD patterns, the peaks corresponding to Au0 (2θ =38.18°, 44.39°, and 64.57°) for the planes (111), (200) and (220), respectively, were not observed, which suggests that gold was present as nanosized-gold particles (<4nm). The low Au content (0.7wt.%) in addition to the small size of the gold particles did not permit their detection by this technique. The appearance of Co3O4 peaks (2θ =31.27° (220), 36.85°(311), 44.81° (400), 59.35° (511), 65.23° (440)) was observed in Au/Co3O4 from spinel (311) plane (Fig. 1). In accordance with the XRD patterns, the increase intensity of Co3O4 peaks with Co/Ti atomic ratios is attributed to the increase of the crystallite size of Co3O4 in the sample. In the samples with low Co loadings, no characteristic Co3O4 peaks were observed, possibly due to amorphous phase. 3.3 TEM and HRTEM The TEM images of Au/Co3O4–TiO2 catalysts are given in Fig. 2 . The average particle sizes of Au on various supports are listed in Table 1. It shows that the average particle sizes of Au were all between 1.5 and 3nm on various Co3O4–TiO2 supports. It demonstrated that the DP method indeed yields high dispersion of Au metals. The gold nanoparticles were observed as dark spots in Fig. 2. They were homogeneously dispersed on Co3O4–TiO2 support. TiO2 from Evonik Degussa has both anatase and rutile phases. Co3O4 deposited on the anatase TiO2 only because anatase TiO2 has more hydroxyl groups which provide the anchoring sites. The TEM images show that gold particles were nanosize, in consistent with the XRD results. In this study, uniform dispersion of gold nanoparticles with diameter less than 4nm and narrow size distribution was obtained by using DP method. Particle size distributions were obtained; and they are presented in Fig. 2. The gold particles can be observed as small dark spots which are in contrast with the support. More than 200 gold nanoparticles supported on the Co3O4–TiO2 catalysts were counted and measured; the corresponding histograms are reported in Fig. 2. Fig. 3 shows the TEM image of Au/Co3O4–TiO2 catalyst after 400h time on stream in PROX reaction. Some of small gold particles aggregated. The average particles size increased slightly from 2.5 to 3.7nm after reaction. The results show that the Au particles were still quite small after reaction. The Au particle size did not increase any more even after 400h time on stream, indicating that Co3O4–TiO2 could stabilize Au particles. This indicates that the size of the gold particles was preserved after the reaction. This effect can be explained in terms of strong interaction between the gold and the reducible metal oxide support and Co3O4. HRTEM was also used to investigate the particle size of Au. Based on the several images of HRTEM, more than 150 particles were counted and the size distribution graph was made. Co3O4 formed very small particles without definite shape on anatase TiO2 surface. At high magnification (Fig. 4 ), Co3O4 particles were observed by the presence of ordered fringes with a space distance between crystal faces of 0.243nm typical of crystalline Co3O4. Au particle size was ∼3nm. Most of them were deposited on TiO2 in adjacent to Co3O4. As it can be clearly seen, the nanoparticles typically presented the {111} and {200} planes that belong to the fcc metallic gold structure; and therefore they were oriented along the [011] direction. However, these gold nanoparticles presented different morphologies, generally 5-fold symmetry twinned structures such as icosahedra and decahedra which tend to be slightly more stable in small sizes. Since anatase TiO2 has more hydroxyl groups than rutile TiO2, most of Au particles were deposited on anatase TiO2. HRTEM images proved this hypothesis. 3.4 TPR To investigate the reduction properties of the supports upon addition of gold, H2-TPR experiments were carried out and the results are shown in Fig. 5 . The TPR profiles of gold catalysts differ from those of the corresponding bare supports depending on the type and strength of interaction of the metallic species with the support. The higher temperature features were attributed to the reduction of the Co3O4 or bulk TiO2. The first reduction occurred at about 520°C and it has been associated with the formation of titanate species. The titanate species is more difficult to reduce and the cobalt titanate reduces to Co metal at even higher temperatures. Therefore, this peak was assigned to bulk reduction of TiO2. The maximum of the first peak was located at significantly lower temperature than that of the surface Co3O4 (398°C), in agreement with other studies which have shown that the presence of noble metal increased the reducibility of the support [40]. A shift to lower temperature was also observed on Au/Co3O4–TiO2 (peaks at ∼100°C and ∼290°C, respectively) as compared to the Au-free Co3O4–TiO2 oxide (peaks at 289°C and 343°C). The two peaks in the reduction profile of Co3O4 correspond to a two steps reduction process (Co3O4 to CoO and CoO to Co0, respectively). The lower reduction peaks were generally explained by the hydrogen spillover from metal to support [14]. In this case, the high temperature reduction process on Co3O4–TiO2 oxide is controlled by the slow bulk diffusion of the oxygen vacancies created at the oxide surface [41]. 3.5 XPS XPS analysis was carried out to obtain information about the electronic states of Au, TiO2, and Co3O4. XPS spectra of Ti 2p in the Au/CoO x –TiO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 6(a) and Table 2 . The binding energies of Ti 2p1/2 and 2p3/2 in pure TiO2 are 464.4 and 458.8eV [42], respectively. The spectra indicate that Ti in Co3O4–TiO2 were all in Ti4+ state, but the heterogeneous environments of Ti4+ result in the broadening of Ti4+ 2p XPS spectra. It is known that Evonik Degussa P25 TiO2 contains anatase and rutile structures. There is a broadening in the intensity of Ti 2p3/2 peak and Ti 2p1/2 peak with an increase in Co/Ti ratio from 1/99 to 3/7 on Au/Co3O4–TiO2 catalysts prepared at pH 7. It indicates an increase in Ti4+ state and the heterogeneous environment due to mixed oxides. For Au/Co3O4–TiO2 prepared at pH 7, there is no significant change in the binding energy of Ti 2p, varying at most within ±0.2eV. Even with an increase in Co/Ti ratio, the binding energy shift was less than 1.8eV, which indicates that the absence of Ti3+ state as Ti 2p binding energy of Ti3+ is 1.8eV lower than those of Ti4+. Since XPS is a surface-sensitive technique, this strongly suggests that Ti species on the surface of the mixed oxide was in the form of Ti4+. The XPS spectra of Co3O4 corresponding to Co 2p peaks are shown in Fig. 6(b). They are characterized by the spin orbit components Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 15eV apart. As for pure Co3O4, the broad and asymmetric spectra are fitted with the components arising from two cobalt species [29]. The results are confirmed from the XRD patterns shown in previous section. The Co 2p3/2 at 780.4eV is indicative of Co3+, whereas the Co 2p3/2 at 781.6eV associated with the shake up satellite peak at about 6eV from higher binding energy is indicative of Co2+ [29]. With an increase in Co3O4 loading, the intensity of Co 2p peak increased. The shift in BE of Co 2p with Co/Ti ratio are tabulated in Table 3 . The binding energy of Co 2p on TiO2 surface shifted to higher BE (eV) as shown in Fig. 7(a) and Table 4 . The spectra of Au 4f region are shown in Fig. 6(c). According to the literature [42,43], each gold species shows two peaks, owing to Au 4f7/2 and Au 4f5/2 transitions. The peaks for bulk metallic gold are centered at 84.0 and 87.7eV [42], while the peaks for Au+ can be observed at 85.5 and 89eV [43]. Peaks corresponding to Au3+, in the form of Au(OH)3, at 87.7 and 91.4eV [44] were not observed. Table 5 shows the central BE and compositions of gold species on Au/Co3O4–TiO2 with various Co/Ti ratios. In general, the concentration of metallic gold in Au/Co3O4–TiO2 was lower than that in Au/TiO2. In this study, the XPS spectra of gold peaks have been deconvoluted to three types, i.e., Au0, Au+ and Au3+. The composition of Au+ on Au/Co3O4–TiO2 was higher than that on Au/TiO2. Fig. 7 shows that Au species exists in two states, one is metallic gold Au0 and the other is oxide gold Au+. Table 6 shows the electronic states of gold before and after reaction. The Au/Co3O4–TiO2 catalyst prepared at pH 7 had the surface composition of about 80.7% Au0 species and 19.3% Au+ species and the Au0/Au+ ratio was lower than those of other catalysts. The concentration of metallic gold in the used catalysts was higher than that of the fresh one. The cationic Au was reduced to metallic state by CO and H2 during reaction. On Au/TiO2 catalysts, gold nucleates probably at oxygen defect sites of titania and remains highly dispersed and in good contact with the support. The gold atoms directly in contact with titania are positively charged and highly stable, Doping with Co3O4 increases the number of oxygen defects in titania, and thus leading to a higher concentration of strongly bound gold atoms. 3.6 Catalytic activity on PROX reaction It has been reported that Au particles with 3nm particle size have the highest activity for CO oxidation [45]. A strong interaction between Au and the reducible supports, such as TiO2 and Co3O4, yields a higher catalytic activity than that supported on unreducible support. There has been much debate concerning the nature of the active site of these catalysts. Bond and Thomphson [46] proposed a model where Au atoms at the interface between the Au particle and the oxide are the active oxidation centers. Okazaki et al. [47] concluded that the oxygen-rich surface of TiO2 is important in the consideration of real Au/TiO2 catalysts prepared by the DP method and calcined in air as the final preparative step. They concluded that electron transfer and orbital hybridization at the interface may be the source of the catalytic activity. In our present study the correlation of catalytic activity with oxidation state of gold for Au/Co3O4–TiO2 catalysts supports the influence of metallic gold on CO oxidation. The morphology of promoting oxide comprises the (i) crystalline or amorphous character, (ii) the type of crystalline structure that may affect the oxygen binding energy, abundance of the oxygen vacancies and (iii) size and shape of the oxide phase affecting the length of the perimeter of active Au/promoter oxide interfaces [48]. Dekkers et al. [49] indicated that Co3O4 supported on Pt/metal oxide improved the performance of CO oxidation, it was suggested that Co3O4 may be an oxygen supplier to Au/metal oxide. Cobalt ion promoted the adsorption of O2 on Au by an increase electron back donation into the anti-bonding orbital of molecularly adsorbed O2. The results in this study are in accord. Figs. 8 and 9 show the effect of Co/Ti atomic ratio on the catalytic activities and selectivities of the catalysts. Adding Co3O4 could modify the catalyst and suppress H2 oxidation. Since limited oxygen was used and H2 oxidation was suppressed on Au/Co3O4–TiO2, therefore CO could have higher probability to react with oxygen. Au/Co3O4–TiO2 (5:95) was the best catalyst among all the catalysts. It showed high CO conversion and high CO selectivity at 80°C in fuel cell operation temperature. The catalytic activity of Au/TiO2 catalyst increased with an increase in temperature until it reached the maximum CO conversion at 80°C, the CO conversion then decreased at 100°C. Au/Co3O4–TiO2 (5:95) had a higher CO conversion than the other catalysts when the temperature was >65°C. Some researchers [50–53] also reported that Co3O4 addition improved the performance of catalyst. It was agreed that Co3O4 could raise the selectivity efficiently. The catalyst was very stable if the reaction temperature was below 100°C. Both CO conversion and selectivity did not change after 400h time on stream. It is well-known that CO could adsorb on Co3O4 and Au. However, CO is more strongly adsorbed on Au particles. Most researchers [30–38] have concluded that Au is in the semispherical shape on the support if the particle size is around 3nm and CO is strongly adsorbed on the perimeter of the Au and support. (6) CO+*→CO* Under reaction condition, large amount of H2 and CO were present, it is believed that some Co3O4 was reduced to CoO. CoO is p-type semiconductor and oxygen can adsorb on its surface [54]. (7) O2 +*→O2* The adsorbed oxygen oxidized CO molecules to produce CO2. (8) 2CO*+O2*→2CO2 +3* However, we believe this reaction is slow. O2 can dissociately adsorb on Au particles. (9) O2 +2Au→2AuO* (10) AuCO*+AuO*→2Au+CO2 Co3O4, on the other hand, is an n-type semiconductor and tends to lose lattice oxygen on surface (OL) in the presence of adsorbed CO [54]. The lattice oxygen can be restored through adsorption of oxygen on the vacancy as: (11) CO*+OL →CO2 +□ (12) 2□+O2 →2OL where □ denotes the vacancy in the lattice. H2 also can adsorb on Au particles. However, it is an activated process [54]. H2 is weakly adsorbed than CO on Au. The presence of cobalt oxide could withdraw electron from Au, thereby suppressing the adsorption of H2 and resulting in suppressing hydrogen oxidation in the PROX reaction [55,56]. 4 Conclusion Gold catalysts supported on Co3O4–TiO2 with different molar ratios were prepared and tested for the preferential oxidation of carbon monoxide in hydrogen stream. Reducible metal oxides such as Co3O4 and TiO2 were found to be suitable supports for PROX reaction because of their nature to donate oxygen. Among all the catalysts Au/Co3O4–TiO2 with Co/Ti molar ratio of 5/95 showed the highest CO conversion even at 80°C. TEM images showed that 1% Au/Co3O4–TiO2 catalyst had gold particle sizes in the distribution range of 1.5–3nm. The average gold particle size was 2.5nm. From XPS, one can understand that the gold oxide species were Au0 and Au1+. Most gold oxide species were metallic oxide, Au0 along with few species of Au+. The better performance of Au/Co3O4–TiO2 for CO preferential oxidation in H2-rich gases is due to the presence of Au+ species stabilized by cobalt oxide. On the basis of the increased reducibility of the oxides, the beneficial effect of gold consists in the promotion of the oxygen mobility. Thus the amorphous nature and promoting effect of Co3O4 on TiO2 was a suitable support to deposit Au. There is a strong metal-support interaction between Au and Co3O4–TiO2 binary oxide support. On Au/TiO2 catalyst, gold nucleates probably at oxygen defect sites of titania and remains highly dispersed and in good contact with the support. The gold atoms directly in contact with ceria are positively charged and highly stable, doping with cobalt oxide increases the number of oxygen defects in titania, thus leading to a higher concentration of strongly bound gold atoms. In the PROX reaction, these gold species remained positively charged and strongly bound to titania. In conclusion, the Au/Co3O4–TiO2 catalysts performed much better than Au/TiO2 and Au/Co3O4 catalyst. A synergistic effect was present. coredata.dc:description: A series of Au catalysts supported on Co3O4–TiO2 with various Co contents were prepared. Co3O4–TiO2 support was prepared by incipient-wetness impregnation with aqueous solution of Co(NO3)3 on TiO2. Gold catalyst was prepared by deposition–precipitation at pH 7 and 65°C. The catalysts were characterized by ICP-MS, XRD, TEM, HRTEM and XPS. The catalytic performance of these catalysts was investigated by preferential oxidation of carbon monoxide in hydrogen stream (PROX). The reaction was carried out in a fixed bed reactor with feed of CO:O2:H2:He=1.33:1.33:65.33:32.01 (volume ratios). Au/TiO2 catalyst had both high CO oxidation activity and high H2 oxidation activity. Adding suitable amount of Co3O4 on Au/TiO2 could enhance CO conversion to a higher extent and suppress H2 oxidation. On Au/TiO2 catalysts, gold nucleates at oxygen defect sites of anatase TiO2 and remains highly dispersed and in good contact with the support. The gold atoms directly in contact with TiO2 are positively charged and highly stable. Doping with cobalt oxide increases the number of oxygen defects on TiO2, thus leading to a higher concentration of strongly bound gold atoms. The amorphous nature of Co3O4 along with TiO2 not only enhances electronic interaction between Au and Co3O4–TiO2, but also stabilizes the nano-size gold particles, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity of CO towards higher extent.
coredata.dc:title: Au/Co3O4–TiO2 catalysts for preferential oxidation of CO in H2 stream
